front.title: Hardening DNSSEC against collision weaknesses in SHA-1 and other cryptographic hash algorithms

list.t: 2005: Theoretical 2^63 attack on SHA-1 by Wang Xiaoyun et al.
2010: DNS root zone signed with RSASHA256 https://www.root-dnssec.org/
2011: NIST formally deprecates SHA-1 for digital signatures, and disallows it after 2013 https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-131a.pdf
2013: IETF recommends RSASHA1 for use in DNSSEC
2014: CA/Browser forum sunsets SHA-1 in X.509 WebPKI certificates after 2015 https://cabforum.org/2014/10/16/ballot-118-sha-1-sunset/
2015: SHAppening free-start collision demonstrated in SHA-1 https://sites.google.com/site/itstheshappening/
2017: SHAttered classical collision demonstrated in SHA-1 https://shattered.io/
2019: IETF deprecates SHA-1 for use in DNSSEC
2020: SHAmbles chosen-prefix collision demonstrated in SHA-1 https://sha-mbles.github.io/
